Arrangements are being made by
the Publicity Board to take the pictures of campus leaders to be filed
in the offices of the Baltimore newspapers and in the files of the Publicity Board. The decision was
made this week after negotiations
were completed with Bachrach
studios. About thirty or forty pictures will be taken,during the coming week. Different organizations
will be represented in the files by
their respective heads. Over threefourths of the faculty at Hopkins
have been photographed and their
pictures placed on file.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS LETTER, MARCH 14, 1924
ENGINEERING STUDENTS
PLAN BASEBALL LEAGUE
A plan to establish an interdepartmental engineering baseball
league has met with great favor
among the engineering undergraduates at Homewood. There had
been some attempt to establish such
a league during the basket-ball season but on account of the closeness
of mid-year examinations, the project had to be abandoned. However, at the present time, with the
finals nearly three months off, and
with the gradual spread of "spring
fever," the "great American game"
seems just "to hit the spot."
The AIechanical Engineers have
the edge on their fellow engineers
in that they have already started
practice. The Civil Engineers plan
to begin practice some time this
week.
A definite schedule has not yet
been prepared but a number of students are working on it now and
are rapidly bringing it into shape.
Definite announcements will be
made in the very near future.
Interest in these games promises
to be very great because of the
great rivalry existing among the
four departments of the engineering school. The games will be
much better than the usual amateur performances because there
are quite a number of men in the
engineering school W ith prep
school records in baseball. These
men are unable for lack of time to
go out and work earnestly for the
varsity squad, but nevertheless
will come out and play for the;r
ilep:rtment.

DATE OF MILITARY BALL
SET FOR APRIL 11
Announcement was made today
that the Military Department will
give a Military Ball on the evening of April 11, in the Civil En0-ineerinc, Hall.
This will be the first attempt to
stage this type of a dance at Hopkins. Other colleges, usually esmilitary institutions,
sentially
make a practice of holding military balls, it was pointed out, and
the Military Department can see
no reason why such an affair
should not be a success at Hopkins.
A committee, consisting of Wilg,is, chairman, Griffith and Rowland, has been appointed and it
will have complete charge of the
affair.
"Further information about the
ball will be forthcoming later,'
said Chairman Wilgis. "However,
it will be well for all of the fellows to remember the date, April
11th, and keep it open if they want
to be present at a thoroughly enjoyable affair." If the ball is a
success it will be continued in the
future.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS LETTER, MARCH 14, 1924
ENGINEERING STUDENTS
PLAN BASEBALL LEAGUE
A plan to establish an interdepartmental engineering baseball
league has met with great favor
among the engineering undergraduates at Homewood. There had
been some attempt to establish such
a league during the basket-ball season but on account of the closeness
of mid-year examinations, the project had to be abandoned. However, at the present time, with the
finals nearly three months off, and
with the gradual spread of "spring
fever," the "great American game"
seems just "to hit the spot."
The AIechanical Engineers have
the edge on their fellow engineers
in that they have already started
practice. The Civil Engineers plan
to begin practice some time this
week.
A definite schedule has not yet
been prepared but a number of students are working on it now and
are rapidly bringing it into shape.
Definite announcements will be
made in the very near future.
Interest in these games promises
to be very great because of the
great rivalry existing among the
four departments of the engineering school. The games will be
much better than the usual amateur performances because there
are quite a number of men in the
engineering school W ith prep
school records in baseball. These
men are unable for lack of time to
go out and work earnestly for the
varsity squad, but nevertheless
will come out and play for the;r
ilep:rtment.

DATE OF MILITARY BALL
SET FOR APRIL 11
Announcement was made today
that the Military Department will
give a Military Ball on the evening of April 11, in the Civil En0-ineerinc, Hall.
This will be the first attempt to
stage this type of a dance at Hopkins. Other colleges, usually esmilitary institutions,
sentially
make a practice of holding military balls, it was pointed out, and
the Military Department can see
no reason why such an affair
should not be a success at Hopkins.
A committee, consisting of Wilg,is, chairman, Griffith and Rowland, has been appointed and it
will have complete charge of the
affair.
"Further information about the
ball will be forthcoming later,'
said Chairman Wilgis. "However,
it will be well for all of the fellows to remember the date, April
11th, and keep it open if they want
to be present at a thoroughly enjoyable affair." If the ball is a
success it will be continued in the
future.
